misuses.misuse: CWE-327: Use of a Broken or Risky Cryptographic Algorithm
misuses.description: The password is hardcoded and can be easily obtained by an attacker.
misuses.recommendation: Use a secure password generation algorithm, such as bcrypt or Argon2, to generate a salted hash of the password. Store the salt and hash in a secure location, such as a password vault, and never hardcode them.

misuses.description: The username and password are hardcoded and can be easily obtained by an attacker.
misuses.recommendation: Do not hardcode credentials. Store them in a secure location, such as a password vault, and never use them in plaintext.

misuses.misuse: CWE-330: Use of Insufficiently Random Values
misuses.description: The salt value is not securely generated. It can be easily predicted by an attacker.
misuses.recommendation: Use a secure random number generator, such as SecureRandom, to generate the salt. Store the salt in a secure location, such as a password vault, and never hardcode it.

misuses.description: The key length is too short and can be easily brute-forced by an attacker.
misuses.recommendation: Use a larger key length, such as 256 or 512, to make the encryption more secure.
